Scheme 1 Cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides to yield cyclic organic carbonates. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Proposed general reaction mechanism of CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides in the presence of a Lewis acid (M+) and a nucleophile (I−). Scheme 2 Fig. 1 Structural representation of styrene carbonate (SC), styrene glycol (SG) and the dimer, which may account for different diphenyl dioxane isomers, formed in the reaction of styrene oxide with CO2 in the presence of zeolite catalysts. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Calculated structure of the NaI cluster (4 ionic units) at PBE periodic boundary conditions. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Calculated structure of the NaI cluster (4 ionic units) embedded inside the NaY cavity with two framework aluminum atoms, at PBE periodic boundary conditions. Atom colors are: blue = silicon; pink = aluminum; red = oxygen; brown = sodium and dark purple = iodine. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Adsorption of ethylene oxide on zeolite Y embedded with the metal iodide cluster: (a) LiI/LiY and (b) NaI/NaY (one framework aluminum atom); (c) LiI/LiY-2 and (d) NaI/NaY-2 (two framework aluminum atoms). Atom colors are: blue = silicon; pink = aluminum; grey = carbon; white = hydrogen; red = oxygen; light purple = lithium; brown = sodium; dark purple = iodine. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Structure of the transition states of the proposed general mechanism of the reaction between ethylene oxide and CO2: a) LiI custer and b) NaI cluster. TS1: Nucleophilic attack of the iodide anion to the epoxide; TS2: reaction of CO2 with the formed haloidrin and TS3: intramolecular cyclization. Atom colors are: grey = carbon; white = hydrogen; red = oxygen; light purple = lithium; brown = sodium and dark purple = iodine. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Structure of the transition states of the proposed general mechanism of the reaction between ethylene oxide and CO2; a) TS1 on NaI/NaY; b) TS2 on NaI/NaY; c) TS3 on NaI/NaY; d) TS1 on NaI/NaY-2; e) TS2 on NaI/NaY-2 and f) TS3 on NaI/NaY-2. Atom colors are: blue = silicon; pink = aluminum; grey = carbon; white = hydrogen; red = oxygen; brown = sodium; dark purple = iodine. The reaction of epoxides with CO2 to afford cyclic organic carbonates was studied over zeolite Y impregnated with metal iodides. The experimental results indicated that formation of styrene carbonate is significantly higher on zeolite Y impregnated with KI compared to KI alone. The conversion and selectivity increase with the loading of impregnated KI on the zeolite, although the epoxide/iodide molar ratio were in the range of 86 to 220, among the highest ever reported for this reaction. A periodical DFT study indicated that metal halides are stabilized upon embedding inside the zeolite Y cavity and interact with the framework counter cations. The theoretical study of the reaction pathway, considering the CO2 cycloaddition to ethylene oxide as model, indicated that the opening of the epoxide ring is the rate-determining step, in agreement with the experimental results that showed a correlation between conversion and the KI loading. The energy of activation is lower on the zeolite/metal halide systems, explaining the higher activity of the metal halides when embedded within the zeolite cavity. The calculations indicated that the reaction occurs on two opposite framework aluminum sites having the embedded metal halide between them. Whereas the epoxide interacts with the framework counter cation of one site, the metal iodide interacts with the counter cation of an opposite site, providing the perfect alignment for the nucleophilic attack and leading to the preferred geometry for the transition state, which resembles a SN2 type mechanism, with nucleophilic attack of the iodide occurring on the opposite side of the ring oxygen atom. This remarkable behavior is characteristic of enzymatic reactions and stresses the importance of host-guest supramolecular catalysis occurring on zeolitic systems. Keywords Zeolites CO2 Cyclic Organic Carbonates Enzymes Metal Halides 1 Introduction Zeolites are crystalline aluminosilicates, with pores of molecular dimensions [1]. Upon ammonium-exchange and calcination, they are used as acid catalysts in many industrial processes [2]. The shape selective properties [3] of zeolites are relevant and widely exploited in many catalytic processes [4]. The enzyme-like behavior of zeolites has been previously suggested for the carbonylation of methanol and dimethyl ether (DME) [5], as well as for Diels-Alder cycloadditions [6]. Nevertheless, the concept has been proposed many years ago [7] and the term zeozyme is used to refer to metal complexes encapsulated inside the zeolite cages [8]. We have shown that zeolites may also behave as solid solvents, with the ability to perform traditional nucleophilic substitution reactions upon impregnation with metal halides [9–12]. The results were interpreted as being due to the ionization of alkyl chlorides inside the pores, with subsequent nucleophilic attack by the dispersed bromide anions within the pore structure, similar to what happens in polar solvents. Recent calculations indicated that metal halide ion pairs inside the zeolite cage stabilizes the carbocations, also suggesting an enzyme-like behavior of the zeolites [13]. Cyclic organic carbonates have great industrial interest. They are used as electrolytes in lithium batteries [14], green solvents [15], intermediates in the synthesis of polycarbonates [16], among other uses. They are normally produced from the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides [17,18] (Scheme 1 ). We have recently shown [19] that zeolite Y impregnated with different metal halides are active catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic organic carbonates from the reaction of CO2 with epoxides. The best results were achieved upon impregnation of KI on potassium-exchanged zeolite Y (KI/KY). The results were interpreted in terms of the potassium counter cations, as Lewis acid sites, activating the epoxide ring, whereas the impregnated iodide behaves as nucleophile to opening the epoxide ring. We wish to present experimental and theoretical results that show evidence for supramolecular catalysis in the synthesis of cyclic organic carbonates on zeolites impregnated with metal iodides. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Experimental section The KI/KY systems were prepared by the following procedure. A parent NaY zeolite (40 g) was initially stirred with 1 mol.L−1 solution of KNO3 in deionized water (900 mL) at 60 °C for 24 h. The resulting solid was filtered and carefully washed with deionized water and named KY zeolite. The freshly prepared KY zeolite (10 g) was stirred at 60 °C for 24 h with 200 mL solutions containing different concentrations of KI in deionized water. Then, the water was carefully removed in a rotary evaporator and the solid was dried overnight to yield the zeolite impregnated with KI. The amount of KI was varied in order to obtain different loadings. The materials were characterized by X ray fluorescence (FRX), X ray Diffraction (XRD), nitrogen adsorption and X ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), being named KI(%)/KY, where the numbers in the parenthesis represent the approximate wt% amount of iodide obtained by FRX. The catalytic reactions were carried out in batch mode, using a 100 mL Parr reactor. Prior to the tests, the catalysts (500 mg) were treated in an oven at 200 °C for 4 h. They were rapidly transferred to the reactor, which was then loaded with 5.0 mL (439 mmol) of styrene oxide and pressurized with CO2. The system was heated to 100 °C for 12 h, keeping 50 bar of pressure. At the end, the reactor was brought to room temperature and atmospheric pressure. The liquid phase was diluted with 20 mL of dichloromethane and the catalyst was separated by filtration. The liquid phase was then analyzed by gas chromatography coupled with a mass spectrometer to obtain the conversion and selectivity. 2.2 Theoretical methods The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were implemented using periodic boundary conditions (PBC) and the codes available in the Quantum Expresso package [20]. The coordinates of all atoms were optimized on the basis of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the exchange and correlation functional developed by Perdew, Burke and Ernzehof (PBE) [21]. The ion cores were described by the Vanderbild ultrasoft pseudopotentials [22]. The electronic state was expanded in plane waves basis set with an energy cutoff of 60 Ry. Brillouin zone sampling was restricted to the Γ-point. The structure of the primitive unit cell of zeolite Y was considered in the calculations totalizing 144 atoms. The cell lengths are a=b=c=17.697Å. For the metal iodides, a cluster comprising 4 ionic MI units (M= Li or Na) was considered to describe the crystal lattice. The charge density of the ions was computed using the Bader analysis [23]. The energy of adsorption ( E a d s ) of ethylene oxide (EtO) was used to measure the strength of the absorbate-zeolite interaction and calculated by: (1) E a d s = E ( M Y + E t O ) − [ E ( M Y ) + E ( E t O ) ] where E ( M Y + E t O ) is the total electronic energy of the LiY or NaY zeolite structure with the adsorbed EtO; E ( M Y ) and E ( E t O ) are the energies of the zeolite LiY or NaY and of the free adsorbate molecule, respectively. The embedding energy ( E E m b ) of the metal iodides inside the zeolites Y cage was calculated to evaluate the stabilization of the metal iodide clusters inside the zeolite Y pore structure. The energy was calculated by: (2) E e m b = E ( M Y + M I ) − [ E ( M Y ) + E ( M I ) ] where E ( M Y + M I ) is the total electronic energy of LiY or NaY impregnated with the metal iodides; E ( M Y ) and E ( M I ) are the energies of the zeolite LiY or NaY and of the isolate metal iodide clusters, respectively. We considered two scenarios to embed the metal iodide cluster inside the zeolite cavity and to study the reaction mechanism: (i) with one framework aluminum atom and the respective compensating cation (MI/MY) and (ii) with two opposed aluminum atoms and the respective compensating cations (MI/MY-2). The structure of the transition states and the associated energy barriers were calculated using the Minimum Energy Pathway (MEP) method [24]. In this approach, MEP is determined by constructing and optimizing a set of images, equally spaced along the potential energy surface of the system between the initial and the final states, using the Climbing-Image Nudged Elastic Band (CI-NEB) method [25]. Eleven images were used to calculate each MEP and their geometries were optimized to establish the minimum energy path on the potential surface of the system, until the energy variations were below 0.05 eV⁄Å. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Experimental studies 3.1.1 Characterization of the catalysts Table 1 shows the composition and surface area of the potassium-zeolite systems. The atomic Si/Al ratio did not significantly change upon ion-exchange and impregnation. The amount of impregnated iodide varied from 5.1 to 12.9 wt% on the zeolite according to the FRX analysis. The impregnation was uniform throughout the zeolite pore system; the chemical (FRX) and external surface (XPS) Si/K atomic ratios were virtually the same, indicating that KI was well dispersed within the zeolite porous framework. Thus, there was no significant agglomeration of KI on the outer surface of the zeolite or forming isolated clusters. The surface area decreases upon impregnation, indicating that the KI clusters may occupy significant space inside the pores and cavities of the zeolite structure. The XRD patterns were almost the same in all zeolite systems (Fig. S1). The characterizations indicated that ion-exchange and impregnation did not significantly affect the structure of the zeolite. 3.1.2 Catalytic studies Table 2 shows the conversion and selectivity in the reaction of CO2 with styrene oxide. On the zeolites impregnated with KI, besides styrene carbonate, styrene glycol (Fig. 1 ) was also observed as product, and it may be associated with the hydrolysis of styrene oxide by some remaining water in the system. The parent NaY and KY zeolite did not produce styrene carbonate, indicating that the presence of impregnated iodide is essential for the reaction to take place. The blank reaction, in the absence of any catalyst, showed no conversion, whereas the reaction of the styrene carbonate with water, under the same conditions, gave 6% conversion with formation of styrene glycol as the sole product. It is interesting to note that the major product on NaY and KY was diphenyl dioxane (possibly different isomers), identified on the basis of the mass spectrum. This product may be associated with dimerization of styrene oxide inside the zeolite pores, although no conclusive reaction pathway may be conceived to explain its formation. It is worth mentioning that the same product was observed on the reaction of CO2 with styrene oxide in the presence of MOF catalysts [26,27], but no explanation for its formation was provided either. Yet, this product was observed upon the treatment of styrene oxide over Montmorillonite [28]. Authors explained the formation of the dimer upon the protonation of the oxygen atom of the epoxide and nucleophilic attack by another epoxide molecule, followed by cyclization. The conversion and selectivity to styrene carbonate increases with the loading of KI on the zeolite. The best results were achieved with KI(13)/KY, where 95% conversion and 98% selectivity to styrene carbonate were observed. Compared with pure KI, the zeolite systems were significantly more active. They lead to higher conversion of the epoxide using considerably higher epoxide/iodide molar ratio. These data indicate that the impregnation and dispersion of KI within the pores of zeolite Y gives a significantly more active catalytic system. The dimer was not observed over the impregnated zeolites, suggesting that in the presence of a stronger nucleophile (I−), the production of the cyclic organic carbonate is the preferred pathway, possibly involving the lowest energy barrier. Styrene glycol was also observed, but the selectivity decreases with the increase of the KI loading, in agreement with the stronger nucleophilicity of iodide compared with water. 3.2 Theoretical studies 3.2.1 MI and MI/MY systems Figure 2 shows the calculated structure of NaI, comprising 4 ionic units, at PBE level. A similar structure was found for LiI, considering the same ion designation. Figure 3 exhibits the calculated structure of NaY zeolite embedded with the NaI cluster, at the same level of theory, considering two framework aluminum atoms. The structure of the LiI cluster embedded inside LiY is similar, considering the same ion designation. We chose to study Li and Na as cations to facilitate the calculations, but the general trends can be extrapolated to potassium cation for correlation with the experimental system studied. There is a slight enlargement of the distance between the ions upon embedding the MI cluster inside the zeolite Y cavity. The detailed values can be found in Tables S1 and S2 of the Supporting Information. This may be explained by the interaction of the iodide ion (Ib) with the compensating cation of the zeolite structure. The distance between the Na+ counter-ion and the Ib anion is 2.914 Å, shorter than the average distance between the ions in the isolated NaI cluster, computed as 3.045 Å. The same trend was observed with the lithium iodide cluster, but with lower magnitude. As a general trend, the MI clusters are less tightly bound upon impregnation inside the zeolite cavity, with the magnitude being less significant on LiI embedded on LiY. These results suggest that, upon embedded inside the pores of the zeolite, sodium iodide is more dispersed and interact stronger with the zeolite Y structure than lithium iodide does. The charge distribution calculation was assessed, and the results are shown in Tables S3 and S4 of the Supporting Information. As a general trend, the average charge on the iodide anion slightly decreases upon embedding the cluster inside the zeolite pores. This is a consequence of the interaction with the zeolite cations. Therefore, the electrostatic interaction between the ionic species of the metal iodide cluster slightly decreases, as a function of the separation of the ions inside the zeolite cage. The calculated embedding energy was – 5.9 kcal.mol−1 and – 11.1 kcal.mol−1 for LiI/LiY systems considering one and two framework aluminum atoms, respectively. The values for the sodium systems were – 7.0 kcal.mol−1 and – 21.3 kcal.mol−1 for one and two framework sites, respectively. These data indicate that sodium iodide is better stabilized inside the pores of zeolite NaY than lithium iodide is on zeolite LiY. The results are consistent with the structure of the embedded MI clusters, as well as with the calculated charges, which indicated a better dispersion of sodium iodide inside the cages, especially when two framework aluminum atoms are considered, suggesting that electrostatic effects play a major role in the stabilization of the metal iodide clusters inside the cavity. 3.2.2 MI cluster and MI/MY system catalytic study Scheme 2 depicts the proposed general mechanism of CO2 cycloaddition to ethylene oxide. M+ refers to a Lewis acid, possibly a metal cation. TS1 refers to the nucleophilic attack of the iodide anion to the activated epoxide, leading to the opening of the ring and formation of an haloidrin intermediate. TS2 is associated with the reaction between the adsorbed haloidrin intermediate with CO2 to afford a metal-carbonate intermediate, which upon intramolecular cyclization (TS3) yields the cyclic organic carbonate, restoring the nucleophile and the Lewis acid site. In order to facilitate the calculations, ethylene oxide (EtO) was chosen instead of styrene oxide, but the general trends can be extrapolated. The non-catalyzed gas phase reaction between CO2 and EtO presented an energy of activation of 69.1 kcal.mol−1 at the same level of theory. This value will serve as comparison to the results computed for the different catalytic systems studied. The first step is the adsorption of ethylene oxide (EtO) on the metal cations, which act as Lewis acids Table 3. shows the results for the isolated metal iodide clusters and the impregnated zeolite systems. As a general trend, the adsorption is stronger on lithium systems than on their sodium counterparts, which reflects the stronger Lewis acidity of the lithium cations. Adsorption is more favored on the systems containing two framework aluminum atoms, possibly due to electrostatic effects. Figures 4 a and 4b show the structure of the adsorbed ethylene oxide on LiI/LiY and NaI/NaY, whereas Figs. 4c and 4d depict the same adsorption on LiI/LiY-2 and NaI/NaY-2, respectively. When one framework aluminum atom is considered, the adsorption of the epoxide takes place on the MI cluster, preferentially on the metal cation opposed to the framework aluminum atom. On the other hand, when two framework aluminum atoms are included in the system, the adsorption occurs on the counter-ion of the second framework aluminum atom, opposed to the site that is interacting with the metal halide cluster. This may explain the stronger adsorption of the epoxide when considering two framework sites. It also aligns the system in a more favorable configuration for the nucleophilic attack, which is the subsequent step of the schematic mechanistic pathway. Figure 5 shows the structure of the transition states of the proposed general mechanism of the reaction between EtO and CO2 in the presence of LiI (Fig. 5a) and NaI (Fig. 5b) clusters. TS1 refers to the transition state for the nucleophilic attack of the iodide to the activated epoxide ring. It can be observed that the geometry is not the preferred one, with the iodide anion attacking at the same side of the ring oxygen atom. In TS2, the CO2 molecule reacts with the formed haloidrin to yield a metal-carbonate intermediate. Finally, TS3 shows the transition state for the intramolecular cyclization, with the leaving of the iodide anion, which also shows a geometry with departure of the iodide and attack of the oxygen atom on the same side of the carbon atom. The calculated structures of the transition states (TS1 to TS3) of the proposed reaction pathway of the CO2 cycloaddition to EtO on NaI/NaY and NaI/NaY-2 zeolite systems are shown in Fig. 6 , whereas Table 4 shows the energy barriers for each transition state. The structures of the transition states are similar for the lithium-zeolite systems and are presented in figure S2 of the supplementary materials. One can see that the rate-determining step in all systems studied is TS1 that involves the nucleophilic attack of the iodide ion to open the activated epoxide ring. All catalytic systems presented lower energy of activation compared with the uncatalyzed gas phase reaction. The barriers are 11.2 and 15.2 kcal.mol−1 lower on LiI and NaI, respectively, than in the gas phase. Additionally, sodium halides were more reactive than the respective lithium halides because of the strength of the electrostatic interaction between the ions, making the iodide anion more nucleophilic when sodium is the counteraction instead of lithium. Embedding the metal iodides inside the zeolite Y cage decreases the energy of activation compared with the isolated MI clusters. Nevertheless, there is a significant difference in the barriers when two framework aluminum atoms are considered in the calculations. The barrier on NaI/NaY is 45.0 kcal.mol−1, slightly lower than the value of 53.9 kcal.mol−1 computed for the isolated NaI cluster. This fact may be explained by the similar structures of the transition state TS1 on both catalytic systems. The nucleophilic attack of the iodide ion takes place at the same side of the epoxide oxygen atom, which is not the most favorable geometry, leading to higher energy barriers. On the other hand, when two framework aluminum atoms are considered, the energy of activation for TS1 drops down to 28.7 kcal.mol−1, indicating that the reaction should occur faster than in the case of NaI/NaY and the isolated NaI cluster. When considering two framework aluminum sites, the nucleophilic attack of the iodide takes place at the opposite side of the ring oxygen atom. This is the preferred geometry for the ring opening of epoxides and is similar to the traditional SN2 mechanism, leading to lower energetic pathways. There is a perfect alignment for the transition state, with the epoxide complexing with the counter cation of one framework aluminum site, whereas the counter cation of the second framework aluminum atom interacts with the metal iodide cluster, affording a favorable geometry for nucleophilic attack and ring opening. Hence, at least two framework aluminum sites are necessary to efficiently catalyze the reaction. The same trend is observed for the lithium systems, but with absolute values slightly higher. As mentioned early, the electrostatic interaction between the ions in the embedded LiI system is stronger than in NaI, making the iodide ion less nucleophilic. The energy barrier for the transition state TS2 is similar for all the systems studied. The reaction of CO2 with the formed haloidrin intermediate occurs through the Eley-Rideal mechanism, in which the free CO2 molecule interacts with the adsorbed haloidrin, with little influence of the catalyst structure. Nevertheless, the transition state TS3 is also significantly affected by the presence of two framework aluminum atoms. Similar to what was computed for TS1, the geometry of TS3 is favored when two framework sites are considered; the departure of the iodide anion takes place on the opposite side of the nucleophilic attack of the oxygen atom to yield the cyclic organic carbonate, resembling a SN2 type mechanism. 3.3 Rationalization of the experimental and theoretical results The experimental results of styrene carbonate production stressed the higher activity of KI impregnated on the zeolite Y structure. The conversions were higher even with considerably high epoxide/iodide molar ratios in the experiments involving the zeolite systems. In fact, these are some of the highest epoxide to nucleophile molar ratio reported in the literature for the synthesis of cyclic organic carbonates, indicating the high reactivity of the zeolite system. The theoretical results pointed out to the stabilization of the metal iodide inside the cage. The zeolite structure behaves similarly to a solvent, decreasing the electrostatic interaction between the MI ions, and making them more loosely bound inside the cage. The magnitude of this effect depends on the alkali metal cation. Thus, Li+ and Na+ would interact strongly with the iodide anion inside the cage than K+ does, making the iodide ion less nucleophilic. This hypothesis has been verified in a previous study [19], where LiI/LiY and NaI/NaY were less active than KI/KY in the conversion of styrene oxide to styrene carbonate at 50 °C. Nevertheless, we also reinforce this conclusion with NaY impregnated with NaI and KI (Table 5 ). One can clearly see the higher activity of NaY impregnated with KI, confirming that the nature of the impregnated metal iodide plays an important role. The results can be interpreted in terms of the interaction between the ions inside the zeolite cage, as shown in the calculation with Li+ and Na+ iodide systems. Since K+ is larger and more polarized than Na+, it becomes more loosely bound to the iodide ion inside the cage, increasing the nucleophilicity of the iodide anion and making it more prone to open the epoxide ring. Calculations also indicated that nucleophilic attack of the iodide ion to the activated epoxide is the rate-determining step. The carbonation proceeds through an Eley-Rideal mechanism, without significant interference of the catalyst. The final step is the intramolecular cyclization to form the organic carbonate and departure of the iodide ion. It is also dependent on the catalyst structure but, in general, the barrier is higher compared with the first step. Calculations agree with the experimental results. The epoxide conversion and selectivity to styrene carbonate are higher when the loading of KI on the zeolite increases. This is consistent with the nucleophilic attack of the iodide ion to styrene oxide being the rate-determining step; typical of second order kinetics, dependent on the concentration of the epoxide and the iodide anion inside the zeolite pore network. In a previous study [9], on the rearrangement of cyclopropylcarbinyl chloride over zeolite NaY impregnated with different loadings of sodium bromide, a pseudo-first order kinetics was observed, consistent with the ionization of the alkyl chloride to form the bycyclobutonium cation as the rate-determining step. Therefore, there was no dependence on the concentration of the impregnated bromide in the rate of the reaction, opposite to what was found in the present study. It is interesting to stress the high epoxide to iodide molar ratio on the experiments with the zeolite catalysts. They are among the highest ever reported in the literature, indicating the high reactivity of KI inside the zeolite structure. It is worth mentioning that KI is a possible catalyst in the industrial process of ethylene carbonate production from the reaction of CO2 and ethylene oxide [29,30]. The process could be significantly improved by impregnation of KI or other alkali metal halide inside the zeolite pores, as shown by the experimental results. Considering the results of the present study, one can see that the productivity of styrene carbonate is significantly higher on the KI-impregnated zeolites than on pure KI (Table 2). We calculated the productivity, in g of SC produced per g of I− in 1 h, taking the overall conversion and selectivity to styrene carbonate, normalized by the amount of iodide in the medium, calculated from the epoxide/iodide molar ratio, within the 12 h of reaction time, all multiplied by the relationship between the molar masses of styrene carbonate and iodide. Thus, it is evident that impregnation of the metal halide inside the zeolite pores leads to an increase in productivity within 40 to 80 folds relative to pure KI, also reinforcing the increase in catalytic activity of potassium iodide upon impregnation inside the zeolite pores. The calculated productivity (Table 2) is higher than the reported productivity for other catalytic systems [31]. The comparison, however, must be analyzed with care since the reaction conditions were different. The enhanced activity of KI/KY system is due to the interaction of the metal halide with the zeolite structure. One of the iodide ions of the metal halide cluster interacts with the potassium counter cation of the framework. Then, at least one of the other iodide ions become exposed and oriented toward the center of the cavity. The favorable alignment may be achieved when a second potassium counter cation, associated with an opposite framework aluminum site, interacts with the epoxide through a Lewis acid-base pair. This exposes the carbon atoms of the epoxide ring to the iodide ions of the cluster, leading to a favorable geometry for nucleophilic attack. The geometry of the transition state resembles a SN2 reaction, where the nucleophile and the leaving group are oriented opposite to each other relative to the carbon atom. Enzymes are biocatalysts that provides a perfect environment for a specific reaction to take place. In some cases, just a given substrate may react due to the specific host-guest interaction that leads to less energetic transition state, in what is generally known as supramolecular catalysis [32]. Boronat and collaborators discussed the high selectivity of Mordenite in the carbonylation of methanol in terms of an specific framework site that provides a perfect orientation of the adsorbed methoxy group to the 8 membered-ring channel of Mordenite and, therefore, perfectly fitting the transition state with less bulk molecules, such as CO [5]. This situation resembles an enzymatic environment, where the structure of the transition state is perfectly fitted, leading to lower activation barriers. In the present case, the zeolite framework provides a favorable environment for the dispersion of metal iodide clusters, enhancing their nucleophilicity relative to the free metal halide clusters, and significantly increasing the rate of CO2 cycloaddition to the epoxide. In addition, the perfect alignment of the metal iodide cluster and the adsorbed epoxide inside the zeolite cage significantly lower the energy of activation compared with the pure metal iodide, stressing the similarities with enzymes, being also an example of supramolecular catalysis occurring within the pore structure of zeolite Y. 4 Conclusions Impregnation of KI on potassium-exchanged zeolite Y significantly enhances the activity for the CO2 cycloaddition to styrene oxide in relation to pure KI. The conversion and selectivity to styrene carbonate increases as the loading of KI on the zeolite goes up. The zeolite catalysts showed better results than pure KI, even with significantly higher epoxide to iodide molar ratios, which varied from 86 to 220, among the highest reported in the literature. DFT calculations at periodic boundary conditions indicated that metal iodide clusters (LiI and NaI) are stabilized inside the zeolite Y pores through electrostatic interaction with the framework. The metal iodides become slightly more dispersed inside the cage, with NaI being more stabilized than LiI. Calculations of the reaction pathway for the cycloaddition of CO2 to ethylene oxide, as model reaction, indicated that the nucleophilic attack of the iodide anion to the activated epoxide is the rate-determining step for all systems studied, in agreement with the experimental findings. Nevertheless, the lowest energy barrier was found when considering two framework aluminum sites. This configuration provides the most favored alignment, with the epoxide being adsorbed on the counter cation of one framework site, whereas the metal iodide cluster stays in the opposite side, interacting with a second framework site of the zeolite. This alignment leads to a favorable geometry for nucleophilic attack, resembling a SN2 transition state. Thus, the iodide ion attacks at the opposite side of the ring oxygen atom. The remarkable activity of the metal iodide-impregnated zeolites compared with pure KI may be explained by the concept of supramolecular catalysis, where the transition state exactly fits within the environment of the zeolite cage. coredata.dc:description: The reaction of epoxides with CO2 to afford cyclic organic carbonates was studied over zeolite Y impregnated with metal iodides. The experimental results indicated that formation of styrene carbonate is significantly higher on zeolite Y impregnated with KI compared to KI alone. The conversion and selectivity increase with the loading of impregnated KI on the zeolite, although the epoxide/iodide molar ratio were in the range of 86 to 220, among the highest ever reported for this reaction. A periodical DFT study indicated that metal halides are stabilized upon embedding inside the zeolite Y cavity and interact with the framework counter cations. The theoretical study of the reaction pathway, considering the CO2 cycloaddition to ethylene oxide as model, indicated that the opening of the epoxide ring is the rate-determining step, in agreement with the experimental results that showed a correlation between conversion and the KI loading. The energy of activation is lower on the zeolite/metal halide systems, explaining the higher activity of the metal halides when embedded within the zeolite cavity. The calculations indicated that the reaction occurs on two opposite framework aluminum sites having the embedded metal halide between them. Whereas the epoxide interacts with the framework counter cation of one site, the metal iodide interacts with the counter cation of an opposite site, providing the perfect alignment for the nucleophilic attack and leading to the preferred geometry for the transition state, which resembles a SN2 type mechanism, with nucleophilic attack of the iodide occurring on the opposite side of the ring oxygen atom. This remarkable behavior is characteristic of enzymatic reactions and stresses the importance of host-guest supramolecular catalysis occurring on zeolitic systems.
coredata.dc:title: Evidence for supramolecular catalysis in the synthesis of cyclic organic carbonates over zeolite Y impregnated with metal iodides
